description.narrative:
The Gender Action Learning System (GALS) was developed under ON’s WEMAN programme since 2008 with Linda Mayoux and partners. Since 2009 IFAD has been promoting the use of GALS and other innovative household methodologies (HHM) as a mechanism to achieve asignificant and sustainable reduction in rural poverty. GALS and the "Household Mentoring approach" developed as part of the Agricultural Support Programme (ASP) supported by Swedish Sida in Zambia are among the two most comprehensive methodologies promoted by IFAD.
H HM position poor female and male smallholder farmers as drivers of their own development rather than recipients of aid or victims. It enables them to identify and address obstacles in their environment, change gender relations in the household and community, negotiate better prices for their products or better service delivery, and strengthen their asset base1. HHM have been successfully applied in a number of countries and can effectively be integrated into agricultural extension, ruralfinance and value chain development. They increase the pro-poor impact of such economic interventions and can contribute significantly to IFAD´s goal of helping 80 millionpeople out of poverty.
For this project a consortium was formed with local CSOsinRwanda, Burundi and DRC to promote sharing of experiences between three countries, capitalise on the opportunities for linking with IFAD programmes in these countries and to bring in more practitioners from Francophone West Africa. The selection of thesethree countries was based on the demand to provide materials in French and to have locations where participants can learn from HMM in practice. The experience and expertise built up with partners and their community groups in Rwanda will be beneficialforthe other two countries but also for IFAD staff from other Francophone countries.
Unrest in Burundi in April before the elections urged the team to postpone the start of the project in Burundi. The inauguration of president of Burundi Nkrunziza inAugust 2015 for a third term created further unrest and political instability, concentrated in Bujumbura. Despite some continuing violent incidents in specific sites, Oxfam assessed the situation sufficiently safe to start implementation in December 2015with a pre-inception meeting, followed by an official inception workshop in February 2016.

participating-org.narrative: Collectif des Associations Producte agricoles pour le développement

The Confederation of Associations of Agricultural Producers for Development (CAPAD) was initiated in 2003 after the dissolution of PRAUTAO, which had been dissolved following problems in financial management. CAPAD is made up of groups of farmers and breeders from rural areas who have been working together since 2000. CAPAD is today the only organization that brings together farmers' associations in Burundi. With more than 2,013 member groups, spread over 20,130 households, the Confederation has a fairlysolid rural base. CAPAD is made up of 72 sector-based cooperatives. These cooperatives bring together more than 20,130 member households, including 14,560 women and 5,570 men. In this area CAPAD has understood that it must work in synergy with other actors of civil society and other organizations of agricultural producers at the national, sub-regional, regional and international level. At the national level CAPAD is a founding member of FOPABU (Forum des organizations paysannes du Burundi, in which CAPADwas the initiator and invited other organizations of producers who cultivate cash crops: coffee, tea, cotton and oil palm for working in synergy. FOPABU emanates from this will of CAPAD and has just been officially created). CAPAD is also a member of FORSC (Forum for Civil Society Capacity Building -another Oxfam Novib partner). At the regional level, CAPAD is a member of the EAFF (Eastern Africa Farmers Federation) and at the international level, CAPAD is a member of the FIPA (International Federation of Agricultural Producers).
